Info.name: A11_001
Info.Instruction: Use the extract from the index of the atlas as well as the list of abbreviations to fill in the missing words in each sentence.

Info.name: A11_002
Info.Instruction: In this task you are going to compare climatic data of five different places in Africa: Algiers, Conakry, Nairobi, Timbuktu and Walvis Bay. Use the four different maps of Africa to answer the questions.

Info.name: A11_003
Info.Instruction: Answer the following questions, and by so doing you will match four geological features found in South Africa to their locations on the physical map of South Africa.

path.MapName: Swartberg mountains in  the Western Cape

Info.name: A11_004
Info.Instruction: Use the Development Indicator Tables and the three maps to compare development in Kenya, South Africa, Brazil and Japan.

Info.name: A11_005
Info.Questions: Exploring energy production in South Africa
Info.Instruction:
Questions 1 to 10: Use the map of conventional and non-conventional sources of energy to fill in the missing words.
Questions 11 to 13: Use the graph showing Cost of energy production to fill in the missing words.
Questions 14 to 18: Use the pie charts showing Recent and planned sources of energy production in South Africa to fill in the missing words.

path.MapName: Conventional and non-conventional sources of energy
Recent and planned sources of energy production in South Africa

Info.name: G11_001
Info.Questions: Identifying types of spatially referenced data
Info.Instruction: Study Figures 1 to 8. Identify the type or the form of data illustrated from the list of options given.

Info.name: G11_002
Info.Instruction: Study the maps and images at different spatial resolutions and place them in order from the lowest spatial resolution (rank 1) to the highest spatial resolution (rank 4).

path.MapName: Landsat image of a section of Mpumalanga
Spot high resolution image of Barberton

Info.name: G11_003
Info.Instruction:
Each of the maps was generated from information from special sensors at different spectral resolutions.
Question 1–4: Study the map Africa Impact of Climate Change and decide whether each of statements 1 to 4 is true or false.
Question 5–6: Study the map Africa Agriculture and Spectral signature 1 and decide whether each of statements 5 and 6 is true or false.
Question 7–8: Study the map Africa Annual Rainfall and decide whether each of statements 7 and 8 is true or false.
Question 9–10: Study the map Africa Minerals and Spectral signature 2 and decide whether each of statements 9 and 10 is true or false.

Info.name: G11_004
Info.Instruction: Study the map of Africa showing natural vegetation generated from raster data to answer questions 1 to 5 and the map of Africa showing climatic regions to answer questions 6 to 10.

Info.name: G11_005
Info.Instruction: Refer to World Resources: Mining and Industry when answering questions 1 to 5 and to Barberton 2531CC when answering questions 6 to 10.

Info.name: G11_006
Info.Instruction:
Study the maps on Global Inequalities (spatial data displayed as a map) and the tables (spatial database) to answer the following questions.
Refer to the World Political map if you need to locate the countries mentioned in the questions.

Info.name: G11_007
Info.Instruction: Study the four maps of Africa labelled Map 1 to 4 and answer the questions on data capture.

Info.name: G11_008
Info.Questions: Converting vector data into a digital format
Info.Instruction: Study the map layers labelled Layer 1 to 8 and match the correct description for each data layer. Only type in the number for each layer, for example, “X” for layer X.

Info.name: G11_009
Info.Questions: Case study: Using GIS to monitor fires
Info.Instruction: Use the AFIS website to identify the various functions found on the GIS interface of the AFIS website. Type in the number of the figure that matches each description.

Info.name: G11_010
Info.Questions: Identifying GIS data layers in Google Earth
Info.Instruction: Identify the data layers illustrated by each image from the list of options by locating Barberton in Google Earth and activating the various data layers. Zoom in so that it is at the same scale as the topographic map of Barberton (1 : 50 000).

Info.name: M11_001
Info.Questions: Locating exact position on different kinds of maps
Info.Instruction:
Questions 1 to 10: Work from the KwaZulu-Natal provincial map to choose the co-ordinates, or the place that matches the co‑ordinates.
Questions 11 to 18: Study the extract from the Pietermaritzburg topographic map and then choose the correct option to answer each question.

Info.name: M11_002
Info.Instruction: Use the Pietermaritzburg topographic map extract to determine the relative positions of the highlighted features.

Info.name: M11_003
Info.Questions: Calculating magnetic declination and magnetic bearing
Info.Instruction:
Questions 1 to 6: Compare the data in the figure showing magnetic declination information from the topographic maps for Augrabies, Hermanus and Rite to answer the questions.
Questions 7 to 10: Use the Pietermaritzburg topographic map extract as well as the magnetic declination data from that map to decide whether the statements are true or false.

Info.name: M11_004
Info.Instruction: Use the three different maps of Pietermaritzburg to consolidate your understanding of the concept of map scale. Map 1 is a map of the province of KwaZulu-Natal provincial, Map 2 is an extract from the Pietermaritzburg topographic map and Map 3 is a screen shot from Google Maps.

Info.name: M11_005
Info.Questions: Measuring distances on maps and converting to ground distances
Info.Instruction: A number of distance calculations have been performed on various maps. Decide whether the answer given in each instance is True or False. Ensure the maps are at 100% before you take any measurements.

Info.name: M11_006
Info.Questions: Calculating the area of regular features
Info.Instruction: Study the extract of the Pietermaritzburg topographic map and perform the necessary calculations in order to decide whether these statements are True or False. Ensure the map is at 100% before you do the scale calculations.

Info.name: M11_007
Info.Questions: Calculating the area of irregular features
Info.Instruction: Study the Schweizer-Reneke and Paarl images in order to complete this activity on calculating irregular areas. Outline tracings have been made of the built-up area of Schweizer-Reneke from a topographic map, as well as a section of the industrial area from the Paarl orthophoto map. The grid squares in both of these images are 1 cm × 1 cm – remember to use the appropriate scale when performing your calculations. Ensure the maps and tracings are at 100% before you do your calculations.

Info.name: M11_008
Info.Questions: Recognising landforms and slopes from contour lines
Info.Instruction: Test your understanding of contour patterns by answering the questions set on each of the images. As is the case for most maps, assume that north is at the top of each sketch.

Info.name: M11_009
Info.Questions: Recognising slopes and landforms on topographic maps
Info.Instruction: Use the topographic map extracts to test your skill at recognising features and interpreting contour line patterns. Say whether each statement is True or False. North is at the top of each map.

Info.name: M11_010
Info.Instruction: Use the topographic map extracts and their corresponding cross-sections to answer these questions. Note that north is at the top of each topographic map extract.

Info.name: M11_011
Info.Instruction: Two cross-sections using different vertical scales have been constructed between Point A and Point E on the Rite topographic map extract. Use the Rite topographic map extract and both cross-section A and cross-section B to answer these questions.

Info.name: M11_012
Info.Instruction: Use the Rite topographic map extract as well as cross-section A to answer these questions. Cross-section A was constructed between Point A and Point E on the Rite topographic map extract.

path.MapName: Cross-section A through Rite topographic map

Info.name: M11_013
Info.Instruction: Use the contour line sketch and corresponding cross-section to answer these questions.

path.MapName: Contour line sketch and corresponding cross-section

Info.name: M11_014
Info.Questions: Identifying landforms and features on aerial photographs
Info.Instruction: Use the Hermanus: aerial photograph 1 and Hermanus: aerial photograph 2 to answer these questions.

Info.name: M11_015
Info.Questions: Using tone, texture and shadows to interpret aerial photographs
Info.Instruction:
Questions 1–7:Use Hermanus: aerial photograph 1 to help you answer the questions.
Questions 8–13:Use Hermanus: aerial photograph 2 to help you answer the questions.

Info.name: M11_016
Info.Questions: Identifying landforms and features on orthophoto maps
Info.Instruction:
Use the Rite and Pietermaritzburg orthophoto map extracts to answer these questions. Questions 1 to 12 are based on the Rite orthophoto map and questions 13 to 24 are based on the Pietermaritzburg orthophoto map.
Note that north faces the top of each map.

Info.name: M11_017
Info.Questions: Orienting aerial photographs and orthophoto maps with topographic maps
Info.Instruction: Orient the two aerial photographs and the orthophoto map with the topographic map extract of Hermanus in order to determine whether the following statements are True or False.

Info.name: M11_018
Info.Instruction:
Use the topographic map extract, orthophoto map extract and vertical aerial photograph of Hermanus to test the level of your mapwork skills.
Each statement below has two possible answers. In each instance, choose the correct statement.

Info.name: A12_001
Info.Questions: Interpreting climatic information from different images
Info.Instruction: Use the wind roses for Cape Town and Durban and the wind systems map to choose the correct option for each of these statements.

path.MapName: Wind roses for Cape Town and Durban

Info.name: A12_002
Info.Instruction:
Study the physical map of South Africa as well as the Limpopo and Eastern Cape provincial maps in order to answer these questions related to fluvial characteristics.
Questions 1 to 7: Use the physical map of South Africa to answer the questions.
Questions 8 to 12: Use the Limpopo provincial map of South Africa to answer the questions.
Questions 13 to 18: Use the Eastern Cape provincial map of South Africa to answer the questions.

Info.name: A12_003
Info.Questions: Applying knowledge and interpreting data from maps and graphs
Info.Instruction: Study the population distribution and density map as well as the population graph for South Africa in order to choose the correct option for each of these statements.

Info.name: A12_004
Info.Instruction: Choose the appropriate word or number to complete each of the statements based on the South African mining image. You may use each word or number only once.

path.MapName: South Africa Mining – minerals and value of minerals

Info.name: A12_005
Info.Instruction: Study the map showing types of industries and their locations in South Africa and then decide whether each of these statements is True or False.

Info.name: G12_001
Info.Questions: Uses of remote sensing and satellites
Info.Instruction: Decide whether each of the following statements on remote sensing is True or False. Some questions will require you to study the maps and satellite images provided.

path.MapName: World Climatic Regions and Ocean Currents
Sat NOAA image sea level rise

Info.name: G12_002
Info.Questions: Temporal resolution - comparing satellite images and topographic maps
Info.Instruction: Study the topographic map of Memel and the recent satellite image of the same area to identify the changes that have occurred.

Info.name: G12_003
Info.Questions: Working with spatial and attribute data
Info.Instruction: Refer to the tables on physical features (attribute data) and the map of the world (spacial data) and type in the correct answer. Copy the spelling from the tables if in doubt.

Info.name: G12_004
Info.Questions: Data standardisation, data security and data sharing
Info.Instruction:
Census data was used to produce these population maps. The population data was standardised and did not infringe on people's right to privacy.
Questions 1 to 3: The GIS-generated map showing population density of South Africa was created using 2012 census data. Study this map to answer the questions.
Questions 4 to 10: Study the map showing population distribution and density to answer the questions.

Info.name: G12_005
Info.Questions: GIS data integration and identifying layers
Info.Instruction: Study the maps on South African agriculture (Map 1 and Map 2) and identify the data layers in order to answers these questions.

Info.name: G12_006
Info.Instruction: Study the topographic map and maps 1 to 4 showing GIS buffer zones and decide whether each statement is True or False.

Info.name: G12_007
Info.Instruction: Query the spatial data on the tourism map to select the answer to each question. A GIS is able to do similar queries in a few seconds. Refer to the graphs showing international tourist arrivals to answer questions 9 and 10.

Info.name: G12_008
Info.Instruction: Study the map and graphs on South African industries. The statements that follow give an analysis of the spatial data they show. Decide whether each statement is True or False.

Info.name: G12_009
Info.Instruction: Government uses GIS extensively to solve energy supply and demand issues. Study the maps to select the source of energy found in the following regions.

path.MapName: Conventional and Non-Conventional Sources of Energy

Info.name: G12_010
Info.Questions: Application of GIS in the private sector
Info.Instruction: NGOs and the private sector are often involved in mapping conservation projects. Refer to the SADC conservation map and identify the type of protected area each feature is from the list of options supplied.

path.MapName: SADC Tourism and Conservation – related graphs

Info.Instruction: Make use of this extract of a South African map to test your mapwork skills. Note that north is at the top of the page. Ensure that the map is at 100% before you make any measurements.

Info.name: M12_002
Info.Instruction: Use the contour sketch map to choose the correct option in each statement. Ensure the map is at 100% before you make any measurements.

Info.name: M12_003
Info.Questions: Direction, bearing, distance and grid referencing
Info.Instruction: Use the Limpopo provincial map to choose the correct option offered for each statement. Note that north faces the top of the page.

Info.name: M12_004
Info.Instruction: Use the Limpopo portion of topographic map sheet index and the extract from the Tzaneen topographic map to practice grid referencing.

Info.name: M12_005
Info.Instruction: Use the photographs of Graaff-Reinett, Pretoria and Tzaneen to revise your photo interpretation skills.

Info.name: M12_006
Info.Instruction:
By using maps and photographs together we can get a better understanding of the functions and processes that occur on a landscape or in a settlement.
Use the topographic map extract and oblique aerial photograph of Paarl to choose the correct option for each of these statements. (The photograph was taken looking east from close to trig. beacon 348 on Paarl Rock (Paarlrots) in block C1.)

Info.Instruction: Use the Koringberg topographic map extract to help you choose the correct option in each statement.

Info.name: M10_001
Info.Questions: Using alphanumeric grids and co‑ordinates to locate places on maps
Info.Instruction:
Use the South African political map, the Gauteng provincial map and the Pretoria topographic map extract to practise locating places using alphanumeric grids and co‑ordinates.
Use the South African political map to answer questions 1 to 5.
Use the Gauteng provincial map to answer questions 6 to 10.
Use the Pretoria topographic map extract to answer questions 11 to 17.

Info.name: M10_002
Info.Instruction: Maps 1 to 4 show four different types of maps. Each has a different map scale. Compare the maps in order to answer the questions.

Info.name: M10_003
Info.Questions: Measuring distance using the map scale
Info.Instruction: Use the four maps to practise measuring distance using the line scale. Remember to have each map at 100% before performing your measurement.

Info.name: M10_004
Info.Instruction:
Use the extract from the South African topographic map index to locate or name various places according to their map reference numbers. Use the pen or highlighter from the toolbar to subdivide and label the grid blocks.
Note: Map reference numbers are written without any spaces between the numbers and letters and the letters are always in capital letters. For example, Alexander Bay’s map reference number is 2816DA.

Info.name: M10_005
Info.Instruction: Study the map of the Western Cape and its key in order to decide whether each statement is true or false.

path.MapName: Western Cape provincial map and key

Question 1: Use the set of topographic map symbols to help you complete the task.
Questions 2 to 11: Use the Edenburg topographic map extract to practise identifying conventional signs.

Info.name: M10_007
Info.Instruction: Imagine that you are a participant on a walking tour of Johannesburg city centre. Follow the description in question 1 and use the drawing tools to mark your route on the map.

path.MapName: Johannesburg CBD Street Map with walking route highlighted

Info.name: M10_008
Info.Instruction: Use the Johannesburg Central Business District street map to practise measuring bearing. Do not worry too much if your measurements are slightly different from the options offered – you will be given at least three degrees (3°) leeway in tests and exams. However, if your answers are very different from the options offered, you probably constructed your N–S line from the ‘to’ place instead of the ‘from’ place – READ carefully!

Info.name: M10_009
Info.Instruction:
Use the Free State provincial map to decide which option is the most appropriate in questions 1 to 4. Use the tools in the toolbar to measure direction and bearing accurately.
Use the topographic map extract of Edenburg to decide which option is the most appropriate in questions 5 to 11. Use the tools in the toolbar to measure direction and bearing accurately.

Info.Instruction: Use the Moorreesburg topographic map to help you choose whether each statement is true or false.

Info.Instruction: The following questions consist of a series of statements regarding distance measurements on the Pretoria topographic map extract. Info.Instruction: Study the photographs and contour line sketches in order to answer the questions.

Info.Instruction: Classify the countries by selecting the best answer from the list of options.

Info.name: A09_002
Info.Instruction: Study the maps and tables for Kenya, SA, Brazil and Japan and select the correct development indicator.

Info.name: A09_003
Info.Instruction: Study the maps showing South Africa’s biomes and climatic regions and select the best answer for each question.

Info.name: A09_004
Info.Instruction: Refer to the map and graphs and select whether the statement is true or false.

path.MapName: SA conventional, non-conventional sources of energy

Info.name: A09_005
Info.Instruction: Select the best option after comparing the map of world agriculture with the world political map.

Info.name: M09_001
Info.Instruction: Study the labelled contour map and the contour model of the same landscape in order to identify features A to H. Type in the name of the landscape feature.

Info.name: M09_002
Info.Instruction: Refer to the Physical Map of South Africa and the Contour Map of South Africa when answering question 1 to 5. </br> Refer to the Topographic Map of Van Reenen when answering question 6 to 10. Indicate the steepness of slope for each place.

Info.name: M09_003
Info.Instruction:
Study the contour map when answering questions 1 to 5.
Refer to the map of KwaZulu-Natal and the topographic map of van Reenen when answering question 6 to 12.

Info.name: M09_004
Info.Questions: Interpreting vertical aerial photos and orthophoto maps
Info.Instruction:
Refer to the topographic map of Stanger and the vertical aerial photograph of Gledhow (block H4) when answering question 1 to 5. Note that the scale of the aerial photograph is different to that of the topographic map, it is more zoomed in.
Refer to the topographic map of Port Elizabeth and the orthophoto map of Port Elizabeth when answering question 6 to 10. Note that the orthophoto map has conventional signs on it so features are easier to identify.

Info.name: M09_005
Info.Questions: Interpreting orthophoto map images from aerial photograph
Info.Instruction: Refer to the Physical Map of Kwa-Zulu Natal, the topographic map and orthophoto map of Stanger when answering these questions.

Info.name: M09_006
Info.Questions: Reading height off maps and orthophoto maps
Info.Instruction:
Question 1 to 4: Refer to block B4 of the physical map of KwaZulu-Natal. Zoom in to this block and answer the questions. Hint: Use the 'Key' for the map to find the height of each place.
Question 5 to 10: Refer to orthophoto maps 1 to 3 of Van Reenen to answer the questions.

Info.name: M09_007
Info.Instruction:
Study images A to E when answering question 1 to 5.
Hint: You will have to study the key of conventional signs to identify the symbol.

Info.name: M09_008
Info.Instruction: Refer to the topographic map of Van Reenen to answer the questions.

Info.name: M09_009
Info.Instruction: Study the photos and topographic maps A to D to identify the landform. To answer questions 5 to 10, match the contour map to the image of the landform labelled A to F in the chart showing contour lines and profile images.

Info.name: M09_010
Info.Instruction: Identify the landform patterns on the contour map labelled A to K.

Info.name: M09_011
Info.Questions: Measuring distance using a line and ratio scale
Info.Instruction: Use the line or ratio scale to determine the straight-line distance in km between the following places. Note: If you use the ratio scale make sure the maps are at full extent. The line scale of the maps will always be true should you zoom in or out.

path.MapName: Port Elizabeth 3315 DC and DD and 3425 BA

Info.name: M09_012
Info.Instruction:
Question 1 to 5: Refer to the provincial map of Limpopo and match each place to its co-ordinates.
Question 6 to 10: Refer to the topographic map of Stanger and match each place to its co-ordinates.

Info.name: M09_013
Info.Questions: Interpreting information from aerial photographs and topographic maps
Info.Instruction: Refer to the topographic map of Van Reenen and identify the features labelled A to K on the aerial photograph of the same area.

Info.name: M09_014
Info.Instruction: Refer to the topographic map extract of Port Elizabeth and the orthophoto map of the same area. To answer questions 1 to 5, identify the features labelled A to E on the orthophoto map of the North End Lake area. </br> Note that if you zoom in to the same area on Google Earth you will see the Nelson Mandela Stadium next to North End Lake, although it is not shown on the maps. This is because it was built after the orthophoto map and the topographic map were printed. </br> To answer questions 6 to 10, identify the features labelled F to K on the orthophoto map of the area west of the airport. </br> Use the drawing tool to circle places F to J on the topographic map extract.

path.MapName: Port Elizabeth 3315 DC and DD and 3425 BA
Port Elizabeth orthophoto map - North End Lake area
Port Elizabeth orthophoto map - West of airport

Info.name: M09_015
Info.Questions: Identifying settlement patterns and land use
Info.Instruction: Refer to the Map of Witwatersrand Land Use when answering questions 1 to 10.
